awd_titl_txt: SBP: Theories of Social Status and Inequality
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how personal attributes with status value can cease to have status value attached to them.  It is well known that certain personal attributes not intrinsically tried to competence can have status value attached to them so that they are associated with how well people are expected to perform.  This project investigates the removal of status value from attributes, or "status deconstruction," by testing theoretically derived propositions through experiments.  Findings will point to interventions to disassociate expectations for competence from categorical distinctions, which in turn is likely to contribute to equity in task-focused groups and improve the groups' performance.  

The theory is tested via two laboratory experiments. These begin by using established procedures for associating competency expectations with categorical distinctions. Then, multiple theoretically relevant conditions are implemented to remove the association between the categorical distinction and competency expectations.  Data consist of both behavioral data, which are measures of the degree to which participants accept influence from others with different attributes, and questionnaire data, which assess attitudes toward others with different attributes. Results from this experiment will evaluate theoretical predictions about the conditions leading to status deconstruction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the development and experimental testing of a social theory explaining how the value associated with attributes like race or sex changes. Historically, both characteristics have been associated with status in the US, but the status value of both race and sex are changing as women and minorities acquire greater education and occupational prestige. The theory outlined and refined through this award posits that changing reward structures and changing patterns that make interactions more equitable results in belief change about the status of groups. Specifically, we argued and showed experimentally that low status actors are faster to change their status beliefs when rewards distributions and interactions undermine the status hierarchy, whereas high status actors are slower to alter their beliefs, resulting in a period of conflicting status beliefs. Outside of the labatory context, we applied our arguments to racial status beliefs to predict conflicting status beliefs. We predicted that racially minoritized individuals would higher status beliefs for themselves than others would hold for them. We found support for this prediction among Black and Hispanic respondents, but not Asian respondents. Collectively, the two studies develop the logic of our predictions and show varied empirical support. Additionally, this award supported two different graduate students and about a dozen undergraduate students who worked on the experimental data collection, project development, and the graduate students became co-authors with the PI on the manuscripts from the award.
